@matchingbird because in 1611 there was no agreed english word for the animal. the greek and latin hovered between "one horn" and "nose horn". so they turned that into english.they chose uni-corn, english language went with rhino.  nobody knows exactly, but they changed as little as possible.

@travisdon1981 in 1611 it was unclear how the biblical word should be translated.  two words were available: unicorn (lit. one-horn) and rhinocerus, both used in the earlier greek translation but clearly referring to one and the same animal. they plumped for unicorn. later english went w rhino.
